snippet.textDisplay: Before saying all this, I love Dark Souls, so much. I  played it growing up and still do. I‚Äôve loved every game including the original Dark Souls 2. It may be may favorite actually, but scholar of the first sin oh my lord. I won‚Äôt be a hate comment that tells you not to buy either. If you want to purchase this, play it, and experience so much frustration from poor level redesign that you want to throw your controller, so be it. To anyone who will read this though this game is the exact same game as the original, but with so many more enemies added just to kill you and not challenge you. It‚Äôs so infuriating because I love these games. It just feels sloppy and like they pushed it out the door to make some money and tell you ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like a whole new game!‚Äù It‚Äôs a giant dumpster fire.

snippet.textDisplay: This is much harder than dark souls 3 which was my first souls game, the dodging in this game doesn‚Äôt seem to be as effective as in 3, tbh I hardly took damage in dark souls 3 because I would just roll out of the way, in number 2 I feel I roll perfectly and still take massive damage.. which would cause me to use a lot of flasks in 2, I have learned now to be SUPER cautious (even more so than I was before) I was very aggressive in dark souls 3 and it worked well, in this game I just stand around and wait for an opening instead of getting in there doing damage and rolling out and around, not as fun but I still like it.

snippet.textDisplay: This a warning to all those living in a country like mine where there is frequent power outage or unsteady power supply, please don't buy this game forget it's rating forget all what every reviewer said cus what they never tell you is this game has a save system that is easily corrupted. I can't tell you how many times I have play this game only to have my save data corrupted when the lights goes out. It doesn't matter how far you've gone or how careful you are once the lights goes out while you're playing prepare to start all over again. This games was not made for us in 3rd world countries or if you prefer developing nation's.

I honestly think Dark Souls 2 gets much more hate than it deserves. 
Sure there is some garbage bosses. (Twin Dragonriders, Grave Robbers, Royal Rat Vanguard/Authority, Covetous Demon, Demon of Song, Skeleton Lords)

But there was still some great and very memorable bosses.
(Looking Glass Knight, Sir Alonne, Fume Knight, Velstadt, Burnt Ivory King, Smelter Demons, Sinh, Pursuer, Executioner's Chariot)

snippet.textDisplay: My god, this feels just like the initial release of Dark Souls 2. That is _not_ a good thing. I understand "everyone has their opinion" and such and that's all well and good, but to herald this game as some kind of masterpiece is just insulting to the rest of the series.This game and its design is largely a broken mess, and from what I've seen, SotFS doesn't fix anything about that, rather, it amplifies the lazy design problems that plagued the first version. The hitboxes and other mechanics are still just as broken as before. All this seemed to do (apart from bundling all the dlc in one package) is throw more enemies in places they don't need to be. It sticks strictly to the philosophy the entire first version was built around, which is "add more enemies to make it harder." That does _not_ make a challenging game. There is a distinct difference between making a game that is challenging and making a game that is just hard for the sake of being hard. That is where the B-Team that designed Dark Souls 2 sorely misunderstood what the heart of the series was about. Difficulty was never Miyazaki's goal, rather, it was a means to draw you into the game. Making a Souls game for the sake of it being hard with no cohesion or functioning mechanics completely misses the point of the entire series. The Souls games' combat systems work best in one-on-one encounters. In the original Dark Souls 2, there were way too many challenging enemies that clumped together and beat you down not because you're bad at fighting in the game, but because fighting 3+ heavily armored enemies with shields and strong attacks is a preposterously stupid way to inject difficulty into your game. It is just plain lazy design. All SotFS seemed to do was throw stronger enemies all over the place with reckless abandon _for the sole purpose of making the game harder_.

DS2 is the only one in this series that I never finish. (and that also includes Bloodborne, and Demon's Souls)

DS2 is the only one in this series that I never finish. (and that also includes Bloodborne, and Demon's Souls)

I find the design term is very weak compared to the others in the franchise, it looks so much less imaginative that I thought they didn't hire concept artists for the project.
That doesn't include the fact that they reused a lot of stuff (I can not take it as an Easter egg, or story-related factor, it looks more like a lazy work) It is not a bad game, it's just that it lost the passion, and got me bored.

snippet.textDisplay:
Looking through these comments I get the feeling that a lot of people just love jumping on bandwagons.

It also looks like a lot of people haven't even played this game and just like to criticise it because they're now part of the cool new gang who're into the latest game, Bloodborne.

Firstly, I've not played Bloodborne yet and I'm waiting till I've fully completed DS2 before picking it up but I'm sure I will love it.

So far I'm about 60 hours into this game and I'm loving it. The gameplay mechanics and levelling system to just the general environment and all the hidden secrets to find and unlock. The voice acting is also second to none. Overall DS2 is an awesome game and very fun to play. Isn't that why we play games, to have fun?

What I'm getting at is why should this game get so much criticism, just because it's not as good as it's predecessor? It's still an excellent game. Just because it might not be as good as Bloodborne, does that mean it shouldn't be played? By that token, if I'd never played Final Fantasy IX because of how many people would have said how much better VII was, I wouldn't have experienced one of my favourite all time games.

Comparison is the thief of joy.

By that token, if I'd never played Final Fantasy IX because of how many people would have said how much better VII was, I wouldn't have experienced one of my favourite all time games.

snippet.textDisplay: Recommended! Dark Souls 2 is very fun even if you have already played Dark Souls 1. Dark Souls 1 had many glitches that could be exploited to take advantage of the tough game play...Such as killing the Blacksmith for his thunder hammer, then transferring to a new character and upgrading that same hammer using the blacksmith you killed. I had done this and the hammer basically made me a god. Dark Souls 2 may not have as good of a map layout (hidden areas, connecting shortcuts from one place to another) but was a masterpiece. I have not found any exploits tempting me to taste the forbidden fruits so in my experience Dark Souls 2 is more challenging. Both are equally awesome! :)

snippet.textDisplay:
I personally liked Dark Souls 1's graphics far more than Dark Souls 2's. However, I feel as if Dark Souls 2 is mechanically superior. If DkS2 had been released with something closer to what the pre-release looked like, I'd definitely give the graphics trophy to DkS2. Luckily, Scholar of the First Sin brings us one step closer. Unfortunately, I think that that step is the farthest we're going with this game. Bloodborne, amazing looking as it is, is exclusive to PlayStation 4. I play PC, but thats irrelevant to this post. I actually recently finished DkS1 on the PC with my keyboard and mouse. I put 200 hours into that game just to beat it once, and plan to put many more in the future. But with Dark Souls 2, I feel as if I'm more than half way through the game without any clue of what's going on in the story (though, I didn't really know what was going on in Dark Souls 1 for quite a long time either) at around 10 hours... I guess what I'm trying to say is that I feel much more engaged and immersed in DkS1. But I guess there's plenty more to explore in DkS2. Maybe I'm just not looking hard enough. :)

Tips to make DkS2 more challenging are welcome and appreciated, as I've noticed a humongous difference in difficulty gap. What used to be one huge enemy that had difficult move sets to learn is now a horde of smaller enemies with spears. 

Anyways, what are your guys' thoughts? What do you think of Dark Souls 2? What about Scholar of the First Sin?
snippet.textOriginal:

If DkS2 had been released with something closer to what the pre-release looked like, I'd definitely give the graphics trophy to DkS2. Luckily, Scholar of the First Sin brings us one step closer. Unfortunately, I think that that step is the farthest we're going with this game. Bloodborne, amazing looking as it is, is exclusive to PlayStation 4. I play PC, but thats irrelevant to this post. I actually recently finished DkS1 on the PC with my keyboard and mouse. I put 200 hours into that game just to beat it once, and plan to put many more in the future. But with Dark Souls 2, I feel as if I'm more than half way through the game without any clue of what's going on in the story (though, I didn't really know what was going on in Dark Souls 1 for quite a long time either) at around 10 hours... I guess what I'm trying to say is that I feel much more engaged and immersed in DkS1. But I guess there's plenty more to explore in DkS2. Maybe I'm just not looking hard enough. :)

Tips to make DkS2 more challenging are welcome and appreciated, as I've noticed a humongous difference in difficulty gap. What used to be one huge enemy that had difficult move sets to learn is now a horde of smaller enemies with spears. 

Anyways, what are your guys' thoughts? What do you think of Dark Souls 2? What about Scholar of the First Sin?

snippet.textDisplay: I loved the first Dark Souls. it's crazy how much time passed, after I rerolled the game like 6 times in a row, and I still wanted more. After I heard that DS2 will have a better deal without paying for the DLC pack separately I was on edge waiting for Scholar of the First Sin to come out. Bought it as soon as it appeared on Steam. And... the hell if i know what to think of it after 20 hours yet :D it was the same with the first Dark Souls. I was not sure what I'm playing but, there were those epic moments, incredible lore to be discovered in time, and sometimes I was so impressed that I just held my breath and I was staring at the screen and wondering if I really see what I see. I have no idea if this can possibly be better than DS1 was, but I'm sure it has still many surprises.

snippet.textDisplay: Many people say that DS2 is the worst of the series but they don't realize an important aspect of the human mind. Whenever you love something so much you will create great expectations for next iterations of the game and these expectations are usually hard to meet. For example, I played DS1, DS and DS2 in that order and I prefer DS1. But if people play them in other order they will probably like better the first one they played.

Whenever you love something so much you will create great expectations for next iterations of the game and these expectations are usually hard to meet. For example, I played DS1, DS and DS2 in that order and I prefer DS1. But if people play them in other order they will probably like better the first one they played.

snippet.textDisplay:
As much as I really do enjoy Dark Souls 2, it's a poor game when compared to its predecessor. And it's far easier than the first game too. What is perhaps most frustrating about this review is that it is obviously been done by someone who knows nothing about Soul's games. It's such a shame how places like IGN, Machinima, etc. have become one of the worst places to get a review for a game. Why? Because they have more to lose from giving a poor review, maybe they won't get the 'First 15 minutes of Call of Duty 37: Modern Warfare 29, exclusive to IGN'. This is just highlighted by the excellent reviews AW got despite being a horrendous game! It sucks how you can't trust a channel of this size to give you a truly honest and critical game review. And this review highlights it. Dark Souls 2 is a really fun game, but the level design is poor - especially when compared to the first one - most of it makes no geographical sense and just feels like it's been mashed together by a five year old. The enemies can be dull and repetitive, bosses lack imagination and innovation, the game suffers from artificial difficulty spikes by jus throwing more enemies at you instead of producing genuinely challenging ones, and the story/lore lacks substance, depth and
emotional investment that the first one had in abundance. This wasn't meant to turn into a rant of this magnitude, but I'm sick of short, inaccurate and bias reviews from these 'big' YouTube channels.
